entry.title: “Get Rid of ‘Very’ in Your Writing“
entry.content:
Communicating scalar relationships, quantities, outcomes and conditions can be tricky and most writers tend to fall back on the word ‘very’ to convey information. This makes for unclear, and also boring, writing.

It is tempting to rely on ‘very’ to convey information and modify adjectives, but there are words that make your writing more efficient as well as more engaging. Science writing suffers from a perceived necessity for dryness. One of the things that Praxilla Press tries to do is correct that misconception and to bring a more engaging tone to science writing. A simple way to demonstrate that is to look at some substitutes for ‘very __’.

Instead of saying that something is ‘very hard’ tell us that it was ‘difficult’; instead of saying that a finding is ‘very important,’ consider the word ‘crucial’ for example. Substituting an active, dynamic single word for your ‘very __’ phrase helps the reader understand the importance and relevance of your work.

For a great example of 128 words to use instead of ‘very’ check out the infographic from the folks over at Proofreading Services.
